case_id: State of Haryana v. Inder Singh (2002) 9 SCC 588 / AIR 2002 SC 3350
facts: Prosecutrix (PW1) alleged she was raped by Inder Singh (Respondent No. 2) and two others (originally accused, acquitted by Trial Court).
Prosecutrix informed her parents about the incident on the morning of 04.07.1992.
First Information Report (FIR) was lodged on 04.07.1992 at 10:45 AM at Police Station Sadar Bhiwani.
Medical examination of the prosecutrix was conducted on 04.07.1992.
Medical report indicated no external or internal injuries on the prosecutrix.
Vaginal swabs were taken, but the chemical examiner's report regarding semen was negative.
The Trial Court acquitted all three accused persons, disbelieving the prosecutrix's testimony citing delay in FIR and lack of corroborative medical evidence.
The State of Haryana filed an appeal in the High Court against the acquittal.

The High Court upheld the acquittal of the two other accused but reversed the acquittal of Inder Singh (Respondent No. 2), convicting him under Section 376 IPC and sentencing him to 7 years Rigorous Imprisonment.
Inder Singh appealed to the Supreme Court against his conviction.
The State of Haryana also filed an appeal (Cr. Appeal No. 1035 of 1997) against the High Court's judgment upholding the acquittal of the other two accused.
The Supreme Court heard both appeals together.
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - initially relevant, less so after acquittal of co-accused)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The testimony of the prosecutrix (PW1) is credible, reliable, and sufficient for conviction, even without corroboration.
precedents: State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996) 2 SCC 384
State of Himachal Pradesh v. Shree Kant Shekari (2004) 8 SCC 153
State of U.P. v. Pappu @ Yunus (2005) 3 SCC 594
elements: Act was against her will/without her consent.
Identity of the accused (Inder Singh) established by PW1.

counter_arguments.loophole: Sole testimony requires careful scrutiny, especially given acquittal by Trial Court.
supporting_precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614)
Kaini Rajan v. State of Kerala (2013) 9 SCC 113
Raju v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2008) 15 SCC 133

prosecution_arguments.argument: The delay in lodging the FIR (from evening of 03.07.1992 to morning of 04.07.1992) is minor and reasonably explained by the trauma and social circumstances of a rape victim.
precedents: Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1988 SC 696)
Harbans Lal v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1989) 4 SCC 459
State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996) 2 SCC 384
elements: Explanation (trauma, informing parents first) is plausible.

counter_arguments.loophole: Delay provides opportunity for deliberation and potential false implication.
supporting_precedents: Thulia Kali v. State of Tamil Nadu (1972) 3 SCC 393
State of Punjab v. Gurdeep Singh (1999) 9 SCC 87
Rajesh Patel vs State of Jharkhand (2013) 3 SCC 791

prosecution_arguments.argument: Absence of injuries on the prosecutrix and negative semen report do not disprove rape, as injuries are not always present and semen may not always be detected.
precedents: State of U.P. v. Babul Nath (1994) 6 SCC 29
State of Karnataka v. Sureshbabu Puk Raj Porral (1994) 2 SCC 466
Madan Gopal Kakkad v. Naval Dubey (1992) 3 SCC 204
elements: Medical evidence is corroborative, not essential.
Lack of resistance leading to no injuries can be due to fear.
Absence of semen detection is common.

counter_arguments.loophole: While not conclusive, lack of any corroborative medical sign weakens the prosecution case when relying solely on testimony.
supporting_precedents: Narender Kumar vs State (NCT of Delhi) (2012) 7 SCC 171
Krishan Kumar Malik v. State of Haryana (2011) 7 SCC 130
Suraj Mal vs State (Delhi Administration) (1979) 4 SCC 725 (general principle on corroboration when testimony has infirmities)

defense_arguments.argument: The Trial Court rightly acquitted based on lack of corroboration and delay; High Court erred in reversing acquittal without finding the Trial Court's view perverse.
edge_cases: Appellate court's power to reverse acquittal is limited.
Mere existence of another possible view is not grounds for reversal.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415
Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225
Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154

defense_arguments.argument: The delay in lodging the FIR is significant and unexplained, raising doubts about the veracity of the complaint.
edge_cases: The delay wasn't just immediate reporting, but occurred after the victim reached home and consulted parents.
No immediate outcry or report to neighbours/others.
precedents: Thulia Kali v. State of Tamil Nadu (1972) 3 SCC 393
State of Punjab v. Gurdeep Singh (1999) 9 SCC 87
Rajesh Patel vs State of Jharkhand (2013) 3 SCC 791

defense_arguments.argument: Complete absence of medical evidence (no injuries, negative semen report) corroborating the prosecutrix's allegation of forceful intercourse.
edge_cases: Contradiction between alleged forceful act and lack of any physical signs.
Medical evidence does not support the oral testimony.
precedents: Raju v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2008) 15 SCC 133
Krishan Kumar Malik v. State of Haryana (2011) 7 SCC 130
Narender Kumar vs State (NCT of Delhi) (2012) 7 SCC 171

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution relies solely on the testimony of the prosecutrix, which has been deemed unreliable by the Trial Court, and lacks independent corroboration.
edge_cases: Trial court had the advantage of observing witness demeanor.
High Court reversal based purely on re-appreciation of sole testimony.
precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614)
Suraj Mal vs State (Delhi Administration) (1979) 4 SCC 725
Kaini Rajan v. State of Kerala (2013) 9 SCC 113

judgment.outcome: Conviction Upheld. The Supreme Court dismissed Inder Singh's appeal and upheld the High Court's judgment convicting him under Section 376 IPC. The State's appeal against the acquittal of the other two accused was also dismissed.
reasoning: The Supreme Court held that the testimony of the prosecutrix (PW1) was cogent, credible, and inspired confidence.
It reiterated the principle that conviction for rape can be based on the sole testimony of the prosecutrix if it is reliable and trustworthy.
Corroboration is not an imperative rule of law but a matter of prudence, especially if the testimony is implicitly reliable.
The delay in lodging the FIR was considered minor and adequately explained by the circumstances (trauma, consulting parents). Such delay does not automatically create doubt.
Absence of injuries on the prosecutrix does not rule out rape, as a victim might submit out of fear or threat, not necessarily involving a violent struggle.
The negative finding regarding semen in the vaginal swabs is not conclusive proof against rape.

The High Court was justified in interfering with the Trial Court's acquittal of Inder Singh as the Trial Court's reasoning for disbelieving PW1 (based on delay and lack of medical corroboration) was found to be flawed and contrary to established legal principles.
The evidence against the other two accused was found insufficient by both the Trial Court and the High Court, justifying the dismissal of the State's appeal regarding their acquittal.

Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1988 SC 696)
State of U.P. v. Babul Nath (1994) 6 SCC 29
State of Himachal Pradesh v. Shree Kant Shekari (2004) 8 SCC 153 (Although decided later, principles align; the 2002 judgment likely cited similar predecessors like Gurmit Singh)

Bharwada Bhoginbhai Hirjibhai v. State of Gujarat (1983) 3 SCC 217 (General principles on appreciation of evidence)
Prithvi Nath Pandey v. State of U.P. (1994) Supp 1 SCC 459 (Regarding medical evidence in rape cases)
